item.title: Mem Tech Device
item.description: Memory Tech Devices tech device is a feature that nobody that works on x86 has ever heard of. According to their own definition "We're working on a generic Linux subsystem for memory devices, especially Flash devices.". Seems like their goal is to provide an abstraction over a bunch of different memory techs. eg. NAND, NOR flash etc.. It should be noted, that block devices like MMC, eMMC, SD etc do not work with this driver.

item.title: Elf Gottchas
item.description:
Trying to get my hands full with embedded ARM cores this year. Trying few raspberry PI kits. So, first thing, get a boot loader working.

Picked up all the essentials from bootloader section at elinux. Trying to run the tools, I got the following wierdity:

$ ls ./arm-bcm2708hardfp-linux-gnueabi-gcc
./arm-bcm2708hardfp-linux-gnueabi-gcc

$ file ./arm-bcm2708hardfp-linux-gnueabi-gcc
./arm-bcm2708hardfp-linux-gnueabi-gcc: ELF 32-bit LSB executable, Intel 80386, version 1 (SYSV), dynamically linked, interpreter /lib/ld-linux.so.2, for GNU/Linux 2.6.15, BuildID[sha1]=e2801f48a84144e2b40d6083baac317057662b3c, stripped

$ ./arm-bcm2708hardfp-linux-gnueabi-gcc
bash: ./arm-bcm2708hardfp-linux-gnueabi-gcc: No such file or directory

$ ls -l ./arm-bcm2708hardfp-linux-gnueabi-gcc
-rwxr-xr-x 1 hk47 hk47 560424 Jan 25 22:52 ./arm-bcm2708hardfp-linux-gnueabi-gcc

WTF, its an exec file. but, running it causes bash to report an error claiming the file doesn’t exist. Whats going on here ? Lets try strace..

$ strace ./arm-bcm2708hardfp-linux-gnueabi-gcc
execve("./arm-bcm2708hardfp-linux-gnueabi-gcc", ["./arm-bcm2708hardfp-linux-gnueab"...], 0x7ffc79750a70 /* 35 vars */) = -1 ENOENT (No such file or directory)
.....

Ok, so it did try to execv the file, and it returned ENOENT. The execv man page says ENOENT would mean:

   ENOENT The file filename or a script or ELF interpreter does not
              exist, or a shared library needed for the file or interpreter
              cannot be found.

Since the file clearly exist, the candidates now are elf interpreter or shared lib for the interpreter. lets try ldd to see if we get any missing libraries. And since ldd doesn’t know what the fuck is going on, then we try readelf

$ ldd ./arm-bcm2708hardfp-linux-gnueabi-gcc
	not a dynamic executable

$ readelf -a ./arm... | less
    INTERP         0x000154 0x08048154 0x08048154 0x00013 0x00013 R   0x1
      [Requesting program interpreter: /lib/ld-linux.so.2]

$ file /lib/ld-linux.so.2
/lib/ld-linux.so.2: cannot open '/lib/ld-linux.so.2' (No such file or directory)

$ readelf -a /usr/bin/gcc | less
  INTERP         0x00000000000002e0 0x00000000004002e0 0x00000000004002e0
                 0x000000000000001c 0x000000000000001c  R      0x1
      [Requesting program interpreter: /lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2]

$ file /lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2
/lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2: symbolic link to ld-2.28.so

$ pacman --files --list | grep "ld-linux.so.2"
lib32-glibc usr/lib/ld-linux.so.2
lib32-glibc usr/lib32/ld-linux.so.2

$ pacman --sync lib32-glibc
...
$ ldd ./arm-bcm2708hardfp-linux-gnueabi-gcc
ldd ./arm-bcm2708hardfp-linux-gnueabi-gcc
	linux-gate.so.1 (0xf7edc000)
	libc.so.6 => /usr/lib32/libc.so.6 (0xf7ce3000)
	/lib/ld-linux.so.2 => /usr/lib/ld-linux.so.2 (0xf7ede000)

Ok so as can be seen this seems like a case of missing interpreter, so we just need the ld-linux.so.2 file.

So just install lib32-glibc.

item.title: Golang
item.description:
This post is mostly a rant. Be warned, I hate Go, and I hate pretentious people. No disrespect to Ken Thompson though.

Golang , a language created by people who created Plan 9. Plan 9 was an operating system that was supposed to pioneer distributed os. In reality it never picked off. I haven’t seen it and I don’t need to comment on merits or demerits of it.

It also sounds like he has some grudge against Bjarne Stroustrup. Anyway, sounds like somewhere in 2009 he announced along with Ken Thompson, announced Golang. The claim being

"Go was designed at Google in 2007 to improve programming productivity
 in an era of multicore, networked machines and extremely large codebases."

My personal experience with Golang has been kind of a mixed bag. I wasn’t really blown by anything that the language was able to do. I have done much things with C++ , and now very few things impress me, for better or for worse.

A few advantages of language include simple package management (to be read as “no package management”), and no versioning.( Things which are going to be introduced in Golang v2, lol).

After programming in it for about 4-5 months, and migrating a project over from C to golang, my honest opinion is of a language trying to re-invent the wheel, and a language which would end up not being able to do it more properly than its predecessors.

Golang also does many crazy things like growing/shrinking stacks while program is running :/, using some Plan9 function calling conventions, etc.. The language feels very productive, if throwing up a quick code suey is the daily thyng. My biggest complain is re-inventing class objects, and creating arbitrary features like “slices”.. There is literally no advantage in doing that.

slices for example. WhyTF does anyone need slices ? What problem do they solve ? Its just some syntactic sugar, and not even fool proof at doing what it does…impl of slices.

I also feel Rob is very pretentious.He claims Go is simple. I mean sure it is simple, but it doesn’t include all the rich feature sets that other languages have.eg. I want to pass a variable and have guarentee that it cannot be changed by the function…tough luck can’t do that, because, "less is more" or whatever the fk, says Mr.Pike.

He claims Bjarne went all over to heavily promote C++, but, then he himself is promoting the language like crazy. And in any case, language didn’t gain much any traction untill Google put its weight behind the language.

Moreover, adding things like generics, versioning etc… is making the language closer to java anyway… so the simplicity was I think a scam ! Golang 2 does everything Golang is supposedly against…

Error handling , propagation etc is a shit show. Its confused between error handling as done by Java and as done by C.

In any case, I would much prefer working with something like Rust if adopting a new langauge is something that is real priority. Rust will probably be the language (if any ) to replace a system programming language of the future.

References
  • Rust
  • Golang
  • Rob pike
  • Slices

item.title: Electro Chemistry
item.description:
Today is the day I try my first electro chemistry related experiment, after my high school, for the first time. Goal is to produce pottasium chlorate.

Brushing up basics

Alright, so the first thing to do was to brush up some fundamentals of chemistry and electro chemistry, in particular Stoichiometry.

  • Anion : an ion that is attracted by anode, ie. the ion has net negative charge, due to additional electrons.eg. Cl-, O- etc..

  • Cation : an ion that is attracted by cathode, ie. the ion has net positive charge, due to missing electrons. eg H+

  • Oxidation : A state in which electron is lost, and as can be seen, Anions are oxidized.

  • Reduction : A state in which electron is gained, as can be seens, cations are reduced.

  • Mole : A measure of quantity, that deals with measuring number of units (could be electrons, molecules, atoms) , as opposed to their mass. One mole is defined as avogadro’s constant ie. . eg. One mole of charge is equal to avogadro’s constant.. eg. One mole of Chlorine molecule is equal to molecules of . The weight of 1 mole of is 35.453gms (atomic weight of is 35.453 amu).

  • Overpotential : Overpotential is the ability of an anode to not participate into the electrochemical reaction untill additional/over energy/volt/potential is provided. For example, assume that we want to disallow oxygen evolution(formation of oxygen) on anode, then we need an anode that has HIGH oxygen evolution overpotential. These over potentials for a particular anode are different for different elements. See this wikipedia article for overpotentials of Hydrogen, Oxygen, Chlorine for various types of electrodes.

This is important because, electricity works on least resistance principle. So given that we have two Anions, the one that can be evolved with lowest over potential gets priority.

Experiment 1

Alright so the theory is that, to create pottasium chlorate, we simply need to electrolyze a saturated solution of pottasium chloride(salt substitute). I did this without any research, just threw together some rods in a brine solution, and powered it with a 2Amp 5v (10Watt) charger.


Complete failure

As with all things done on a whim, it was a terrible failure. The result was a gooey orange green liquid. (edit: those crystals were Feric Chloride complexes, particularly ) Tried to boil it down, and got a few glowy orange crystals. Were they or types, I have no clue.

Where is my pottasium chlorate ?

Ok so this time more search and finding. Firstly, the last experiment failed because of the use of steel as the Anode. Steel is mostly Iron, the Chlorine anion(the one that goes to anode since it has negative charge), readily combines with Fe, to produce chloride salts of Iron. In other words, the electrochemistry actually consumed the anode as it went on… brutal!

So apparently I need an anode made of either of graphite,lead dioxide,(Mixed Metal Oxide)MMO, or platinum. Basically Anodes that don’t participate in the reaction, but just are inert. I choose Graphite since its the cheapest alternative.

My cell is still a glass bottle with an anode made of Graphite, and a cathode made of stainless steel.At minimum I want to know how much time should I keep the cell running. I can get this info from the following calculations:

Get atomic weight of an element, say oxygen. It is 16 AMU(the unit for atomic weights a really small number of gms), now consider a mole of Oxygen, this is given by AVO’s number, now if we multiply weight per atom into number of atoms, we get the weight in gms.

Similar to above, we get the molar weights of K and Cl, and since we want we sum them up.

For now we assume that 6 moles of electrons are required to get 1 mole of . We get the time and ampers as follows:

Since 1 coulomb of charge passed in a second is considered 1 amp, coulombs of charge passed in second is considered amps. That amount of current would burn all things in its path, so, we can increase the number of seconds, and reduce number of Amps. If we divide 96485.40 by number of seconds in a day we get ~1.12 Amps. So a charge of 1.12 amps for a days time will give us one mole of electrons.

This means in 6 days, we can pass 6 moles of electrons. And in 9 days, we can pass approximately 9 moles of electrons.

Experiment 2
  • 100 ml water, and around 30 mg of Kcl ( 1 mole of KCl is 74gm, so this is 40% of that).
  • Since we would need 1 amps for 6 days for 1 mole of KCl, it means we need 2.5 days, at 1amps. Or, 1.25 days at 2 amps. I decided to pass 2Amps into it. Cell is a simple glass jar with one carbon andoe, and one steel cathode.
  • I also added some of the water from my original failed run, in hopes of salvaging any chlorate it may have. Alas, the only thing it did was give the liquid a wierd color.
  • After 1.25 day, I see that carbon rod was erroded and liquid was a black goo. After freezing it, I got the following
Partial success
  • After that I added water to it, removed the carbon using a filter, and boiled it a bit to remove added excess water. Result was far more cooler :

Partial success
  • 40% of 122gm is around 50gm, so at a 100% efficiency that is what I should have got. 60% would then be around 30gm, but in reality I got around 20gm chlorate. or efficiency of 40%.

item.title: Chlorates
item.description:
Pottasium Chlorate written as is the specialist ingredient that I am after. The first order of business for me was to quickly go through the wikipedia article. It is an oxidizer, just like what we saw in gunpowder post, but, its considered even better oxidizer than (ie. Pottasium nitrate).

What do you mean a “better” oxidizer ?

For this we need to understand what an oxidizer means. At its most basic, oxidation we can think of oxidation of an element as that element reacting with Oxygen, and forming a new compound, that contains the said oxygen bound chemically to the substance other than oxygen before the reaction happened. In general these reactions produce heat, light and other forms of energy.

A relatively easy form of oxidation can be considered to be burning of Magnesium.

Atomic number of Oxygen is 8, and Magnesium is 12, Neon with atomic number of 10 is closest to them and it is stable. Therefore Magnesium will loose 2 electrons, and Oxygen wil gain two electrons, then they will reach the same 10 electron state as Neon. This page describes the above in much greater detail. One another way explanation that I found interesting was the Octet Rule. It basically states that each of those atoms will try to form an electron configuration that is near to a inert gas atomically on a periodic table.

So here we say that Oxygen “oxidized” Magnesium. A simple way to remember this is :

OIL, Oxidiation is Loss (of electrons),

RIG, Reduction is gain (of electrons).

Now what is a better oxidizer ? A oxidizing agent is termed “stronger” if it has a stronger standard electrode potential. The way these are calculated are beyond scope of this page, but you can read more here Oxidation, Reduction, and standard electrode potential

Another way to describe the same as above is using the Electronegativity and positivity of a substance

There could be other measures, for eg How many grams of an oxidizer can oxidize how many grams of substance. And, how much energy is released (although this is also ) kinda dependant on which fuel is being used.

Anyway…

Next steps

So to create a chlorate, all that needs to be done is to electrolyze a salt solution. Crazy ! But it appears that what this does, is to create bleach (KCLO), then chlorite and then chlorate (and if we go too long, then perchlorate). More on the processes involved here Chloro-Alkali Processes

item.title: Sound The Whistle
item.description:
Today, I again stumbled on an interesting article on how the whilstling rockets work. Actually, I was thinking about it since last month, when I experimented with DIY gunpowder.

How do those whistling rockets work ? Really….

Basics of Sound

From my original understanding of Sound, sound is produced when the high frequency (relatively) pressure differences are created in a medium, typically air. Those differences are then picked up by ear drums, and through a complex path, are interpreted as noise by the brain.

The perceived volume is different for different frequencies but same amplitude. Something I had known thanks to the Multimedia and Compression theory lessons of my college years. Kind of easily seen if you think about bats, who’s voice we cannot hear, and dogs, who can hear sound at a higher frequency than us.

Fun(?) fact, as you grow old, your perception of high frequency sounds drops quite a bit. Check it out here!

A related concept called resonance, is simply explained by an example of swing. Resonance periodically increases amplitude of a oscilating/alternating phenomena, by adding small amounts of energy incrementally at right point of time, so that the overall energy increases. Eg. Pushing the swing when they are about to change direction. Anyway, for sound waves to reach enough amplitude, it may sometimes be necessary to bank on the resonance of the container.

Thought experiment 1 : Whistles

A whistle works by blowing air through it. A whistle works in an opposite fashion to resonance. In general a whistle works by producing oscilations by dividing a single pressure stream of air, into two, and these streams to conflict with each other to produce the oscilations. Check out phy of police whistle here

Maybe the smoke produced from the burning of the fuel, produces a flow, that when passed through a whistle like apparatus produces a whistle ? I do remember, that few of those rockets in my early teens that we used to light, did have a set of flute like holes.

However, I do remember, that there were fire crackers with a “white” fuel/mix, that used to also whistle, there was most definitely no apparatus just the plain mixture and an empty tube.

So there is definitely something more to it.

Look online

Alright so the whistle in whistling rockets is due to a chemical effect. Apparently the white mix is called Whistle mix, and it supposedly has a chemical property known as Brisance Brisance appears bad news, it apparently relates to detonation, which is an ability of a mixture to burst at speeds faster than sound, thus their damage energy is high.

Searched again, and there seem to be multiple websites demonstraing the whistle mixes, and apparently there are multiple of these. PyroData is one such example.

Alright, so I needed pottasium chlorate, and sodium benzoate.

Stand back, I am going to try science !

Okay, sodium benzoate is a food preservative, and I have some of it for creating pickles. Since the article says the mixture demonstrates brisance, I am not going to make anything more than 1 to 2 gm at a time.

The only missing part is pottasium chlorate. Again googled some more, and found out that this can be produced using electro chemistry ! Gotta do some work, but will be on this electro chemistry business in a few days.

item.title: Incremental Page Loading
item.description:
Today I propsed a new way to do javascript based dynamic rendering. After migrating from a native blink rendering solution, we moved to javascript. Speed, power , and resources were heavily consumed. I took a look at the same page loading at 3x low speeds. It was painful to see.

We are currently using SVG/XML in order to render pages instead of HTML. The svg is generated from chromium’s compositor, and in that , using skia. We did see that most of the time was clearly being spent on recreating the nodes of the SVG.

Thus the idea that I proposed was to take two frames as SVG, compute the difference, and then only apply the difference. To complicate things, we do want to see partial differences. ie. If two nodes are differing by only one character, then those two should be matched as same nodes with the delta as a change between them.

If it were simply a yes/no comparison, the problem was very simple. It was to compare a two trees. But with the idea that nodes with partial difference should be matched with the closest node in the next frame, it becomes harder. How ? Why ? Lets consider an example:

<svg>
<!-- frame 1 --!>
<tag1 atribs1234> node a
<tag1 atribs1456> node b
</svg>

<svg>
<!-- frame 2 --!>
<tag1 atribs234> node a
<tag1 atribs1236> node b
</svg>

Now, how do you figure out which node from frame 2 should match node from frame 1 ? Intutively, we can see that node a from frame 1 differs with node a from frame 2 by absence of attrib1, so, there is 1 change required to convert frame 1 nodea to frame2 node a. This is a delete operation.

Therefore, we can see that to convert a node from A to B, we need to apply a few operations to it. The number and cost of such operations then is the value that we can give to a pair of nodes, as a score. If we calculate this score for each pair of node, and then get a sorted list of these scores, that would give us the most optimal arrangement of node mappings, such that to convert each node to its corresponding node, the minimum number of operations need to be applied !

There are many well known edit distance /levenstien distance calculation codes that could be deployed to calculate this score.

But wait, we want this to be calculated with each node. These operations are typically non linear. And we have around thousand nodes atleast on a frame. This means we cannot use edit distance. :/

Enter the Engineer

We now need to reduce the time it takes, since this is a critical path operation, the rendering speed and therefore FPS depends on it. So does battery, power and resource consumption.

So first thing to observe here is that, we don’t necessarily need like a 100% proper score, we just need similar nodes. What are other similarity calculators that are easier and cheaper to operate on ?

One similarity calculation could be to just count frequency of character, and use the distribution as a signature. Since most SVG is only a subset of characters, this would most likely give us faster speeds ? Lets think about this, xml tags generally don’t use full a to z characters. It also uses numbers, and mis chars like = “ , etc.. this means, we can convert 200 chars to 50 ish chars.

Now our time complexity looks like O(200+200) for converting a string into signature of 50 characters. And then O(50) to compare the two signatures. This is a clear improvement over O(200*200) worst case for edit distance calculations.

We still can’t get away with the N*N comparision though. Sorting could still be done quite easily and cheaply using something like insertion sort.

Well so that would be it.

Conclusion

To summarize,

  • For each node, convert it to its signature.
  • Then, just do a N*N tabular comparison, and sort it by scores.
  • For each pair with lowest to highest scores,
    • Get changed, added or deleted attributes, and they are the node delta.

item.title: Aluminium Flash Powder
item.description:
Back on subject of fireworks, now that I am pretty much done with gunpowder and rocket candies, now its time for another firework trick mixture, “flash powder”. A flash powder is a mixture of oxidizer and a fuel, just like gunpowder or rocket candy. The reason its called flash powder is because it burns more vigirously and produces a bright flash.

History

The original application of flash powders was in photography. Since there weren’t halogens or any other powerfull sources of light, the effect was produced by actually burning flash powders in order to create the flash.

Ruminations

I know from my middle school that magnesium burns pretty bright, that was the first thing that came to my mind, and sure enough, magnesium is definitely one of the major ingredients in flash powder, its costly though :). Since I am not doing anything serious, and I am not going to become a proffessional pyrotechnic, I am contended with doing simple cheap alternatives.

I will be using aluminium. I had no clue that finely powdered aluminium is actually a fuel that burns almost like charcoal! Nay, better than charcoal, it supposedly can sponteneously ignite at lower tempratures than charcoal.

Some surprises here, in my view , I had thought for the longest time that metals don’t burn except at a very high temprature.. T_T. Looks like metals when their size is small enough act almost like a " sponge " that captures and either adds to, or multiplies the heat absorbed from outside and somehow reaches ignition tempratures, for example iron burns at 816 degree C, but, I have seen iron wool burn with a matchstick.

Similarly aluminium burns at 600 degree C.

Alright, so I am going to combine some coal, aluminium and some nitrate. I hope to get atleast some flash out of this.

Metals as fuels ?
Experiment

I took some coal nitrate and aluminium. Firstly I took them in proportions of 70, 25, 5. 5 being aluminium. And sure enough, it does throw up bright sparks in between coal sparks. It appears quite beautiful.

I tried a second mixture, with ratios 60, 10, 30. And this is quite bright, but doesn’t burn compltely.

Bonus composition : Thermite

Thermite is as a composition is perhaps the best in terms of heat production. This simple mixture is made up of rust of Iron (Fe2O3, Fe2O5 etc) and aluminium. A finely powedered mixture of rust and aluminium can be mixed together througly, and after application of some energy, the oxygen from the iron transfers to the more unstable aluminium. The reaction is highly exothermic, and tempratures enough to melt iron is generated.

This technique is so effective in generating molten iron, that this is used to weld train tracks! For reference train tracks are atleast 15cm by 5cm.

Observations
  • Looks like to burn aluminium properly, you first need some charcoal based fire, that reaches the burning point of aluminium, and then they all vigirously burn and support each other.
  • A small amount of aluminium will throw up bright yellow-white sparks in between the more dimmer reddish coal sparks.
  • Recording this behavior is somewhat of a nightmare due to auto adjusting brightness of all modern cameras.
  • You will be able to feel the temprature difference if you burn a metal fuel (mostly aluminium).

item.title: Dynamic Web
item.description:
Distributing web workload evenly

Just a thought, why is it that pages that load on the browser in modern days are so slow ? Well multiple reasons…

In this post, I will talk about some reasons that I think slow down page perf .

HTTP Archive

This is probably the biggest site to understand the distribtion of content, its bandwidth consumption, and its effect on page load time. Here is a description of bandwidth run for mobiles for 2018.

This is just a small example, the site has lots of good things.

Computing on the client side.

The problem of loading a web page can be distilled into two parts. First, a network constricted resource fetch operation, and second, a compute constricted compute operation.

Web pages designed in the western world, do not represent the average b/w or compute power of people in this world. Therefore for the web to scale, we need newer methods, perhaps, newer more decentralized architectures.

The only way to forever solve this problem is to design web pages by taking into consideration the bandwidth of the user( estimating b/w of the end user is a problem in its own right), there could even be a grade of features and things enabled or disabled based on real time statistics for the given user (this for example is typically done on a video quality degradation).

There are other stop gap solutions, that try to optimize certain aspects of trying to load a page. for example, A data compressing proxy can be used to reduce the strain on end user b/w. Something like a REACT js can be used to more or less stream the changes to the screen, this improves the end user experience, but isn’t that much great on b/w consumption etc etc…

There might still be some scope for translating a given page and its resources based on the end user bandwidth and compute powers on the fly.

item.title: Nitrates
item.description:
Nitrates the oxidizer that we saw last post, is the main ingredient of gunpowder. But now questions is how to produce this ? Or rather how did people produce this in history , and can we produce it ? This post contains some information regarding my information gathering for producing Pottasium nitrate…

In ancient China, and India, it was produced by harvesting the marshy clay and purifying it, add water, then boil, then add ash of particular high pottasium woods, and then , filter the stuff again. Boil to reduce the water, and then let it cool, see the crystals of KNO3 precipitate. They are needle shaped.

Ashes of woods contain carbonates of calcium, pottasium etc.. Then clearly those that contain more pottasium will contain more pottasium carbonate (KCO3). The K in the KCO3 is what we are after, and hence the use of wood ash.

Now, why are there nitrates in marshy lands in the first place ?

Enter The Nitrogen Cycle.

Nitrogen Cycle.

Nitrogen cycle describes conversion of elemental nitrogen (NH2 gas in air) to various compounds of nitrogen, and how nitrogen moves in and out of organic compounds.

This is a diagram from wikipedia commons, that very succicintly describes the cycle.

Alright, so the important part for us is the nitrification cycle, as you can see nitrifying bacteria are the bacteria that take amonia as input, and produce nitrites (NO2), then some other bacteria take the nitrite, and produce nitrates (NO3).

Nitrates(NO3) as you know are the radical that we need to combine with Pottasium (K) to produce the oxidizer Pottasium Nitrates (KNO3).

The conversion of Amonium or Amonia to nitrite is done by classes of bacteria called “Amonia Oxidizing Bacteria” (AOB). One of these are called Nitrosomonas.

2.NH<sub>4</sub>(+) + 3.O2 --> 2.NO<sub>2</sub>(-) + 2.H2O + 4.H(+) ...[yours truly Nitrosomonas, Comammox]

The conversion of nitrite(NO2) to nitrates(NO3) is done by class of bacteria called Nitrite Oxidizing Bacteria (NOB). One of these are called Nitrobacter.

2.NO<sub>2</sub>(−) + O2 --> 2.NO<sub>3</sub>(-) ...[yours truely,Nitrobacter, Nitrospira, Comammox]
Enough with the theory , how do I do it !

So by 17th to 18th century, there were multiple production techniques that were developed that created artificial marshy conditions in hope of harnessing whatever ‘magic’ that created the nitrates in natural marshes. And these people were more or less successful in their efforts.

Alright, so lets think about this, we need as input amonia or amonium thats NH3 or NH4, then, we want as output NO2 and then NO3, alright then, we need oxygen for sure. Turns out, AOBs need CO2 to oxidize NH3 or 4 to NO2, what a bummer !

Historical source for amonia was urine, which contains urea(CH4NH2O). The AOBs will eat urea as well. We then need oxygen (we can get that from air at reasonable rates), and , our friendly bacteria the AOBs , that will take oxygen from air, do their magic, and produce nitrites.

Our other friends, NOBs will then take this nitrite and then convert it into nitrates.

Then we will leech(fancy word for dissolving in water, and seperating by flitration) the nitrates from the said mush, and get a solution of nitrates (potentially calcium nitrates). We can then treat it with KCl to get KNO3.

  • Pottasium is available as Pottasium chloride or Potash.
  • I always wanted to do some hydroponics experiments, probably I will do this when I am dealing with hydroponics.
  • It should also be noted that those nitrates in water are probably calcium/sodium or pottasium nitrates, which when reacted with potash (KCO3) can potentially produce KNO3.

item.title: Gunpowder
item.description:
Alright staying true to my goal, I have some time this week. Read a few things about gunpowder, and fire in general. To summarize it quickly, to make fire, we need fuel, oxygen, and some activation energy. Thinking back at my childhood experiences this makes sense, almost everytime I have lit fire, those 3 were present.

The important bit now is how to get oxygen. Oxygen is at ~20% in air, so a burning substance has 8 in 10 chance of not combusting becuse of lack of oxygen. So, how do we improve flow of oxygen ? The easiest way is to find chemical compounds that release oxygen when they are heated. As we apply the activation energy in the form of fire, this substance will heat, and release additional oxygen into the fuel, that will burn the fuel more vigirously than if it was burnt only by oxygen in air. This particular set of substances used for producing oxygen are called oxidizers.

Thinking back, I do remember reading about the working principle of rockets, that had oxygen along with fuel in its tanks. Also , I don’t remember ever reading that increasing the amount of oxygen during combustion of a fuel, can cause more vigirous combustion of the fuels. Its somewhat dangerous to not teach this.

Coming back to the topic of oxidizers, apparently pottasium nitrate is the most famous of them all, and most ancient of them all. The origin of gunpowder is as is a difficult subject, some people claim it was China, some claim it was India. Well, both of these places have large marshy lands, which are primmed for production of nitrates. More on nitrates in a later post. Since there are more proofs that point to Chinese origins, we will go with that.

For our gunpowder experiment, the general formula is sulphur, charcoal powder, and pottasium nitrate mixed in a 5, 20, 75 ratio. There are a few things to keep in mind, while doing this experiment. First, its related to fire (Agni) so be respectful (alert). Second, do it ultra small scale.

After getting all the required things , I tested each of the substances individually:

Sulphur
  • Applying a match, it will burn with a blue flame.
  • Combustion starts at about 400C.
  • Melts at about 115C.
  • In case of gunpowder, sulphur plays an important role. It first of all is used to equally spread the heat , so that the oxidizer starts releasing oxygen early in the game, this saturates the air around the mixture with oxygen.
Charcoal
  • On application of a match, charcoal powder produced some sparks.
  • Produced by pyrolysis of wood.
  • Hydrocarbon, with varying formula, but typically C6H10.
  • Its a hydrocarbon that burns at around 700+ C.
  • At its max, it can burn at more than 2000+ C.
  • This is the main fuel for gunpowder, given its high energy content.
  • It has many micro porus structures, which can soak up other chemicals. for eg. activated charcoal is used to trap chemicals in water.
Pottasium Nitrate (KNO3)
  • Undoubtedly the MVP of this gunpowder thing…
  • The Nitrate radicle has 3 oxygen atoms.
  • These atoms can be released as diatomic oxygen(o2) on application of heat at around 500C.
  • This release of oxygen is what makes it most usefull compound. Such compounds are generally termed "oxidizers".
  • This doesn’t burn, melts on application of match, and then converts into a white solids (KCo3)
Bonus ingredient Sucrose (C6H12O6)
  • Common house hold sugar is carbohydrate (as opposed to hydrocarbon). Carbs conain oxygen atoms also, in addition to C, and H.
  • It burns at around 300 to 400C, and produces a carbon residue.
  • It melts at 160C.
  • Burning of sucrose produces a LOT of high temprature steam.
Principle of operation

Now that we know how individual ingredients operate, we now simply need to mix them in appropriate proportions. The generally accepted proportions for sulphur : charcoal : nitrate is 5:20:75. This formula has changed quite a bit based on what type wood was used for production of the charcoal.

Alright, so the way this is supposed to work is, sulphur is the first one to melt and ignite, the heated melted sulphur in turn heats the nitrate, causing decomposition, and release of oxygen, this further builds up the heat, causing more oxygen, untill it ultimately reaches charcoal ignition tempratures, and then things just fly from there onwards. Generally accepted simplistic formula is stated as :

	10.KNO3 + 8.C + 3.S ---> 2.K2CO3 + 3.K2SO4 + 6.CO2 + 5.N2
Preparation

Since I want to iterate faster, and there are multiple thing I want to try I will make no more than 5g powder at a time. There are multiple things I need to try, and multiple preparation methods.

The basic thrust of all preparation methods is to introduce as many KNo3 molecules closer to Charcol molecules as possible. And there have been suggested various methods. I will try three main methods, first a simple mixing using mortar pestle, two, using wet mortal pestle, and three with sugar syrup instead of water.

Observations

Various different 5g powder samples prepared and ignited, here are few key things that I noticed.

  • Adding sulphur makes very little impact on burn rate.
  • Method of preparation makes a LOT of impact on burn rate.
  • Reducing KNO3 quantity doesn’t affect much, if, mixing isn’t done properly, it simply leaves residue, but burn speed isn’t affected that much.
  • Adding some sugar causes the mixture to become hard and grainy, this causes more air gaps between the mixtures, and that probably cause better burn rate.
  • Adding sulphur produces a lot more heat than without sulphur.
  • Shit ton of smoke is produced if sulphur is added. If sulphur is not added, the amount of smoke is less than half of with sulphur(approximation).
  • Wet grinding is the way to go, just take some water and keep on grinding the mixture a good about 5 mins. Dry it throughly.
My best attempt

The best mix I obtained was simply Charcoal, Kno3, Sugar in quantities of 30 : 65 : 5, with water grinding. This is safe mixture that doesn’t produce any corrosive gases or anything like it.

Bonus composition "Rocket candy"

Alright adding sugar and Kno3 in proportions roughly 50:50 or 40:60. The mixture is prepared by boiling some water with kno3 and sugar, at VERY LOW HEAT. I repeat VERY LOW HEAT. Stop it as soon as it reaches a melted cheese like consistency. Once its stopped, the mix is like a dough, or a molten glass, its hot, and mouldable, just mold it into a shape. When its cold, it is like a candy.

I did a 10 grams composition, and that stuff produces lots of steam, it also seems to have quite a bit of energy. When I made it burn, it produced some type of motion, so clearly it has energy to propell, hence the name Rocket candy.

In action
dry mixed pottasium nitrate and charcoal powder in ratio of 70 30
wet mixed with 70:25:5 KNO3, Charcoal, Sulphur
wet mixed no sulphur, but sugar, 70:25:5
wet mixed with sugar, 75:20:5
References
  1. Wikipedia Charcoal
  2. Wikipedia Sulphur
  3. Wikipedia Pottasium Nitrate
  4. Wikipedia Black Powder
  5. Wikipedia Rocket Candy

item.title: Fireworks
item.description:
When I was between 7 to 18yrs of age. Fireworks were one of my most fav things to waste time on. I am a Hindu, and there is a festival of Diwali(lights), thats a period where everyone* bursts a bunch of fireworks. Its supposed to ward off evil, and create positive impact. I was always fascinated by the fireworks, and how they work. I used to ask my dad(who is a dokotor) or then one of my paternal uncles, or figure out things by observation. Primary source was observing my brothers, cousins, and friends.

A few things I could figure out on my own, or by observing others. My very first firecracker experience was when I was maybe about 5 yrs old, and I was so scared of it, that I fell while running, away, cried, and swore to never go near it. Then after observing my brother, I finally understood how it works, and it was kinda neat. Use a hot stick to light it, and after a set time it explodes. My elder cousins would take the mis-fired firecrackers cut it open, pour out the powder on a paper, and set it on fire, that would cause a flash of smoke and fire ! It was all very cool to see. I had assumed back then that the powder was something like 1) a match stick, 2) a camphor 3) petrol/kerosene which are all inflamable. I knew the basic science that Oxygen was needed to light fire, but didn’t make the connection, that there are sources of oxygen other than air. For me back then, petrol and gunpowder were both almost the same w.r.t fire, both of them burned vigorously when lit on fire and kind of in a similar way. I knew about camphor because its a central item in Hindu rituals. Same about the matchsticks.

After gaining this new info, I cut open a few fireworks. Observation was that firecrackers that would explode with loud bang contained some kind of silvery-grey powder, when it was on the hand, it reflected a silvery metalic color. Rockets, or firecrackers in general that wizzd and moved around, had a dark, almost black smooth powder, this looked like soot from lamps. Flowerpots etc, had some type of beads. These beads would just glow for a while and then do nothing. For crackers that whistled, there was some wierd powder, that I never understood, it was white in color, and there was nothing like it in any of the other firecrackers.

In my early teens, I used to mix two pots together, or , add another cracker on a rocket, or , use sparkels, and add them into pots etc etc… basicall just basic combining things to see whats produced. I remember doing a pretty good firepot made from rocket dust, and crushed sparkels. There always was one effect that I couldn’t produce…nor did I understand how it worked, no matter how I tried.

WHISTLING EFFECT!. I noticed early on that the firecrackers that produced this whistle were costly. They wizzed like rockets. They had a white powder, that didn’t burn like any of the other powders. It either lit up quite quickly, or just smoked. At this time, I wasn’t “leveled up” to see how were they producing sound. My theory was : “its gotta do with the container they are in just like a whistle”. To my surprise they still produced whistle , no matter the container shape… so it was a mystry to me.

I do remember reading somewhere that there are some special compositions involved in creating black powder, but I never did it, never made the time, Diwali is seasonal affair, and immediately following diwali, we had someducational stuff to do. I do remember reading somewhere that there are some special compositions involved in creating black powder, but I never did it, never got the time.

A few days ago, I came across an interesting article on nitrates leeching into soil, and while reading some of that realized that nitrates are one of the main oxidizers used in fireworks. Finally I am now somewhat stable from some aspects of my life, that I can invest some time in this as a hobby. Starting today I am going to try to DIY a few things, and get a closure on something that I always wanted to do.. in particular create some black powder, and ultimately create a whistle based off of firework compositions.

Lets see how it goes..
